awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Remote Supportive Touch for Health and Wellness
awd_abstract_narration:
Supportive touch plays an important role in how people communicate empathy, compassion, and group affiliation in peer-support health and wellness communities (e.g., holding hands at the start of an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting).  While communication technologies such as Apple's FaceTime have allowed such peer-support meetings to extend their reach through online communities, supportive touch is not currently possible in these online settings.  While researchers have explored the possibility of remotely transmitting supportive touch, few ideas have progressed beyond the conceptual design stage, fewer still have been tested through rigorous empirical investigations, and almost none have been deployed in real-world settings.  The PI's goal in this project is to move the field forward by developing and evaluating projection-based and haptic remote supportive touch technologies in health and wellness domains.  Since the field research will take place at St. Paul facilities for recovery from substance use disorders, the work has the potential for broad impact by helping to address the significant gap between people who need support and those who are able to get it.  Additional broader impact will derive from the fact that one of the prototype systems to be developed as part of this project involves extending and transferring research findings to a commercially available system, where they will be made freely available to the general public.

Two broad research questions drive the investigation:  What variables affect user perceptions of remote supportive touch and how do these variables interact?  And how does remote supportive touch affect relationship formation and maintenance in the wild in the health and wellness domain?  These questions will be addressed through three synergistic activities: development and validation of a questionnaire (for measuring user perceptions of remote supportive touch, which will provide a baseline for rigorous empirical investigations in this domain); a laboratory investigation (that addresses open questions about the impact of three variables on user perceptions of remote supportive touch: relationship with partner, emotional salience of task, and presence of haptic activation) contributing to a model of user perception of remote supportive touch; and a field deployment of two prototypes in the context of peer-support in the health and wellness context (holding hands with a remote partner to promote recovery from substance use disorders) to validate the model in the wild (one of these prototypes serves to transfer research findings on camera-projector collaboration systems to the HP Sprout commercially available technology, while the other leverages novel shape-shifting display technology to represent a remote hand, thereby also contributing to the emerging domain of shape-shifting interfaces).

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Our goal in this project was to help people stay connected across distance. While many tools like videochat (e.g., Zoom, Skype) are readily available, they are all missing the important element of touch. We created three new technologies to consider how people may express touch gestures, such as a hug, holding hands, or a high-five across distance. These technologies included a load-bearing shape-shifting display, a projector-camera system, and a shape-memory alloy on-body haptic system. We also created and validated a new measure for understanding whether a particular approach to transmitting touch is helpful or not. We tested our technologies and measures in the largest user study of mediated social touch technologies to date (over 150 participants). We learned that projector-camera technologies are surprisingly effective at communicating touch, but that adding haptics (i.e., the feeling of warmth and squeezing) helped in high-emotion context between participants who knew each other prior to the study. We shared our process, method, findings, and theoretical reflections with the broader research community through three conference papers, three journal papers, and a granted US patent.

Broader Impact:

First, this project was a compelling way to attract and train students in the STEM disciplines. This included PhD, Masters, and undergraduate researchers. Roughly half of the students who worked on this project came from underrepresented groups in computing. Students who worked on this project have graduated and advanced to STEM careers in US industry and higher education. Second, the insights from this project were used to revise and update an undergraduate course on ?Embodied Computing,? allowing us to train the next generation of creative Computer Scientists and Engineers. Finally, we took special care to disseminate the systems and finding from our work to the general public. This has included demonstrating our system at the Minnesota State Fair over two consecutive years and publishing lay-audience blog posts sharing our findings with the broader community.
